Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Recent Mathematical Advances in Classical, Quantum and Statistical Mechanics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The conference "Recent Mathematical Advances in Classical, Quantum and Statistical Mechanics" will be held at the University of Virginia on March 8-9, 2013. The goal of the conference is to present a survey of some of the major recent results in the area of mathematical analysis which studies the evolution of physical systems with large or infinite number of degrees of freedom in a variety of settings while emphasizing ideas and techniques which are common to these settings. The subject of this conference is one of the most active in contemporary mathematical physics. The conference will bring together leading world-experts in such topics as KAM theory for partial differential equations, rearrangement inequalities in functional analysis, Anderson localization, the study of polaron systems and the non-equilibrium statistical mechanics of coupled anharmonic oscillators. The conference will provide a venue for the dissemination or recent results and methods in the area and will foster further advances in these important topics. A strong component of this conference is educational and aimed at disseminating recent advances in classical, quantum and statistical mechanics. Emphasis will be placed on encouraging interactions between senior and junior researchers. Special efforts will be made to invite and support graduate students, postdocs, as well as mathematicians from underrepresented groups.

The study of the evolution of systems with infinite number of degrees of freedom is ubiquitous in modern science. In the situation pertaining to classical mechanics, a typical example is that of the evolution of a fluid where a degree of freedom essentially corresponds to the velocity of the fluid at some point in space. Since there are infinitely many such points one is looking at a complex system with infinitely many degrees of freedom in interaction. These give rise to nonlinear partial differential equations which feature in a huge number of applications such as the models used for weather prediction. In the quantum case, examples of such systems are the polaron systems which describe the motion of particles in an ionic crystal (structures similar to that of ordinary salt). Another example studied under the name of Anderson localization has to do with the motion of a quantum particle in interaction with a random medium. The latter is supposed to model, e.g., the impurities in a semiconductor. Finally, a third regime where systems with infinitely many degrees of freedom are the subject of very active study is that of statistical mechanics, in particular in the non equilibrium situation. An example of mathematical challenge in the area is to understand the conduction of heat or electricity, not in an ad hoc phenomenological description, but rather through a derivation from first principles: the basic laws of classical or quantum mechanics at the microscopic level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided partial funding for two conferences in mathematical physics held at the University of Virginia. The first conference with title "Recent Mathematical Advances in Classical, Quantum and Statistical Mechanics" was held on March 8-9, 2013. The second conference with title "Harmonic Analysis and the Renormalization Group" was held on April 18-21, 2014. For both conferences about half of the funds was used to support the participation of junior researchers or persons from underrepresented groups.

First conference:

This conference which lasted a day and a half provided a snapshot of current developments in a wide range of topics related to the study of systems with a large or infinite number of degrees of freedom in the different situations or regimes corresponding to classical, quantum and statistical mechanics. Among the total of 7 talks, there were 3 by junior researchers or members of underrepresented groups. Avoiding a cluttered schedule allowed sufficient time for discussion and the interaction of junior participants with the more senior invitees. There were a total of 35 participants, 14 of whom were junior researchers or persons from underrepresented groups.

Second conference:

This conference was a follow-up to the first one, with a stronger focus on one particular hot area, namely, the interface of renormalization group theory and harmonic analysis. The theory of the renormalization group in statistical mechanics and quantum field theory involves a decomposition of random fields into time-frequency atoms and the precise analysis of statistical correlations between these atoms. Such decompositions (such as the wavelet decomposition used in the JPEG image compression standard) are important tools in harmonic analysis. Yet, despite sharing a common subject of study, there has been little communication, until this conference, between the renormalization group and the harmonic analysis research communities. This conference provided an opportunity for the sharing of ideas between these two communities. A strong component of this conference was educational, indeed, many of the talks were two to three hour long minicourses on advanced research topics. For instance, Martin Hairer (Fields Medal 2014) gave a 3 hour minicourse on his latest theory of regularity structures. Among the 8 speakers, 2 were junior researchers. There were a total of 19 participants, 8 of whom were junior researchers or persons from underrepresented groups.

More details about these conferences can be found at the websites:

http://pi.math.virginia.edu/LTconf/

and

http://pi.math.virginia.edu/hargconf/

which are intended to serve as a lasting repository for the information related to these events, accessible to all.
